log Jeremy let's pick back up with the micro kernel you mentioned at the tail

what a micr kernel you know exactly is and then you mentioned the security benefits but maybe if there are other
pros and cons to that sort of a design yeah so the strictest definition of a
micr kernel is a kernel that only does what is necessary in kernel space to
make a a functional user space that is the strictest definition by that
definition Redux is not a micr kernel but the definition that's typically used
is drivers and services run in user Space by that definition Redux is a
microc kernel it isn't a seven system call micr kernel like the The L4 micr
kernel but it is a micr kernel it's 10,000 lines of code and what it does is
provide a framework for file systems that then users space can use to create
file systems and to perform file system operations that's essentially what it
does uh the older kernel before the rewrite had drivers included so it
wasn't a micr kernel it was a monolithic kernel and even older than that if you go all the way back to the original uh
right the original get commit it was a unic kernel so the first thing that
happened was to be able to run processes in user space the next thing that happened was moving drivers into user
space in order to do that we had to write some some special system calls for drivers to hook into but the majority of
system calls in the in the Redux kernel are file system related opening files
Reading Writing seeking closing and duplicating it's pretty much it uh there
are some Timing System calls uh and there are some process control system
calls like exec and sleep things like that well actually clock Nano Nano sleep
or something like that whichever one has the highest resolution is the the one we
Implement what this means is that in user space in Redux you have disk
drivers file system drivers the network stack network drivers the graphics stack
Graphics drivers the input stack input drivers are all programs this is very
different from other operating systems especially other operating systems they're at this level of development uh
because if you do look at other micr kernels they have tended to lag behind
in part because it's difficult to write a micr kernel and also in part because
there isn't a lot of interest in micr Kels but I think after realizing the

architecture put put more strain and slow down the development of these
specific like the networking stack in user space um does it make writing that

are actually really easy to write uh I've written several drivers for
networking devices uh each one takes about a day of research and
implementation effort and uh most of that is looking at Hardware specific
things like registers because actually getting to the point where you're accessing Hardware is not too difficult anymore the the reason why user space
drivers are are so hard and well we could take Linux for example because there are user space drivers especially

use Li USB and Implement user space drivers for devices things like

that is available for a user space driver programmer is the ability to get
Hardware interrupts delivered to the process this does not exist so you can't

system for interrupt delivery so a device driver simply opens a file for
that interrupt and then gets a file event and can read the interrupt

micr kernels easier to develop in now I would say for a new driver the things
you have to do are create a file system to access that device write Hardware
specific code to access the registers of the device and then link the two
together so that you have something come in from user space from another process it tries to open for example dis colon
zero you give it back a a handle when it reads from that handle you read from the
dis and implementing this with this with the scheme uh mechanism in Redux has
been fairly simple and straightforward another aspect of redo is design that uh
that interested me right away is this this concept of everything is a URL
which um you know those of us uh well versed in Linux remember everything is a
file or familiar with that everything is a URL uh seems like a a take on that
that seems more uh holistic or Global can you talk about that design decision
and its implications in the OS so I would say that everything a file
is still the methodology okay uh unfortunately these two things are conflated when people
hear everything is a file in terms of Unix what the original meaning was is
everything can be treated as a file handle not that everything had a path on
the file system uh what that meant was that maybe you would open a network uh socket you
would not open it from the file system in most most unix's you would open it
with a socket call but you would read from it with a read call you would write to it with a
right call and you would close it with a Clos call what redo has done is unify all of this into the open call and it's
something very similar to what Plan 9 did so first we have everything as a file descriptor now we have everything
as on the file system like plan N9 where every networking is is accessed through
the file system you create files you read from them you destroy them from the
file system you are able to do networking operations uh you are able to interact with with the uh windowing
system uh everything you can do in plan N9 you can do from the file system with
a file path okay so now everything is a file descriptor and it's referenced by a
file path now in redo it goes one step further both of those are true and we
add on segmented file systems what this means is that the beginning of of a path
identifies a file system to interact with this file system is implemented by
either the kernel in the case of some of the uh low-level file systems like interrupt handling or by mostly by a
user space process and in order to create a scheme which is what this level
is called in order to create a scheme a user space process opens a file it
creates a file in What's called the root scheme so everything is file based or at
least file path based the reason why I say everything is a URL the easiest way
to conceptualize this for most people is the word URL because you have at the
beginning of the URL you have an identifier of the protocol called the scheme right and you have after that a
path so what what happens in redo is that path gets sent to whatever handles
that specific scheme and then it returns a file Handler which the kernel holds on
to and the kernel uh arbitrates between the two processes it passes all of the
system calls that are that utilize that file descriptor to the scheme Handler
which then passes the results of uh each file descriptor operation back to the
kernel which then forwards it to the process that that uh started the system
call so to do separate like do specific user space programs register as scheme
handlers or something they say I can handle this exactly so each scheme is typically uh owned by one one process so
one process for each scheme and a process can have more than one scheme
usually they don't but sometimes they can in the event uh so for example the
network stack uh especially the new version of the network stack it has TCP
and UDP and IP all implemented by the same process so any operations on those file
systems get sent to the same process but what this means is that you can easily
audit all of the open file descriptors and all of the available paths on the
system who supplies them what is happening to them all of that can be
audited from the Kel level so by asking the kernel for all of the open file
